Results.resulttext: Of the five ESL levels, you’ve tested into level two, which means your English reading and writing skills are severely limited. Your English is limited to basic responses in conversations and you are prone to misunderstandings.

Of the five ESL levels, you’ve tested into level three, which means your English reading and writing skills are rough, but are close to par with your grade level with extra work. You feel confident you can speak basic English, but misunderstandings still happen.

You approach the group of Chinese-speaking students, and they immediately welcome you. Speaking Mandarin, you talk about the differences between China and the U.S.. There aren’t enough night markets here! You complain about how difficult it is to assimilate. It lifts your spirits to have relatable friends, but the group rarely speaks English amongst themselves, so it doesn’t help with your language skills.

You approach the group of English-speaking Chinese kids and introduce yourself. At first they look at you with disdain, but one of the kids welcomes you to the school and strikes up a conversation. The  other kids follow suit and begin chatting too. You struggle to understand everything they say, especially the slang, but you force yourself to speak only in English to them to improve your language skills.

You approach the group of English-speaking Chinese kids and introduce yourself. They look at you with disdain, and one of the kids points at you and makes fun of how you speak and dress. The kids call you a FOB (fresh off the boat) and tell you to go back to China. You walk away quickly, nearly in tears, feeling like everyone in the cafeteria is staring at you. The encounter leaves you both angry and lonely.

The counselor goes with your mother’s recommendation: enroll in regular classes. You find the experience extremely tiring. You struggle with the material, and while you’ve quickly learned English, your grades have tanked due to your initial language barrier and lack of support.

The counselor decides to place you in ESL classes. The classes are meant to help increase your language skills. However, you find the class disengaging: other ESL students speak in their native languages rather than practice English and the teacher seems unsupportive. You find progress is slow.

The counselor decides to place you in ESL classes.. You find your class is exciting: the teacher facilitates engaging group activities, like having the students interview each other. She also teaches you important academic vocabulary that helps in your other classes. This class really helps with your language skills and your grades.

The counselor decides to place you in ESL classes. The classes are meant to help increase your language skills. However, you find the class disengaging: other ESL students speak in their native languages and the teacher doesn’t push the students to try harder. You piece what you can together, but you find the progress is slow.

You agree to the tutoring. You meet your tutor, who also came to the U.S. as a teenager to study in a public school. You hit it off, and the tutor directs his assistance with laser focus. But the extra work is hard and cuts into your free time.

You plead with your mother to let you forgo the tutoring. You’re concerned with the workload at school and you don’t want to add more burdens as you try to adjust to your new life. But while you have more free time, you feel isolated. Once your mother leaves, you don’t have an adult to confide in.

You watch your mother explain to you how to cook basic meals like eggs and soup. She goes over how to shop cheaply but nutritiously. She gives your practical tips, like how to cut fruit and veggies without cutting your fingers, and how to budget for groceries. She gives you all the tips she can so you will be able to take care of yourself. Although boring, the training makes you feel independent, almost heroic, like the superheroes in your favorite comic books.

You drift off when your mother explains how to cook a meal. You think about your experiences in the U.S. so far and how worried you are about trying to meet new friends in this land that is both exciting and lonesome. As your mother finishes her lecture, you nod as if you had paid attention and give her a big hug.

You’d enjoy nothing more than to defend yourself, but you know that if you cause too much trouble you could possibly be expelled from school. As much as the bully’s words hurt, you walk away even as he calls out that you’re a “coward.”

You calmly confront the bully, and remind him that you noticed him turn green dissecting frogs in biology class, so maybe he just has a delicate constitution. The other students laugh. Embarrassed, the bully walks away. You breathe of a sigh of relief.

You calmly confront the bully, and reminding him and his friends of how the other day that you noticed him turn green dissecting frogs in biology class, so maybe he just has a delicate constitution. The other students laugh at the bully.The bully lunges at you and a fight begins. Later, your left eye and right shoulder throbs in pain from the bully’s punches. Your guardians are notified as the school suspends you for three days. Unsurprisingly, your parents are not happy with your behavior.

Although it would be nice to see your family this summer, you feel it’s more important to master English and move toward your goal of getting into an American university. Overcoming your homesickness will be tough, but your family will likely understand and praise your decision.

It’s important you visit home. When you land in China, you're surprised how much you missed the crowded streets.  Enrolling in the summer program would get you closer to your goals, but having time with your family gives you a much needed morale boost.

Thankfully you paid attention when your mother was showing you how to cook. You invite your buddies over and have a great time playing board games and agonizing over yesterday’s pop quiz in U.S. history. It’s a reprieve from studying.

As much as you would like to hangout with your friends, the upcoming test is far too important to mess up. Getting a good grade on the test could propel you closer to your goal of getting an A in the class, so you decide to study alone for the evening.

While preparing dinner for your friends, you accidently cut yourself with a knife so badly the bleeding won’t stop easily. Your friends insist a doctor check it out, but you can’t afford health insurance and don’t know what to do. You search the internet for solutions. You read a “how-to” website, and apply pressure on the wound and raise your arm above your head until the bleeding stops. Writing and typing won’t be much fun this week.

You decide to talk with the school counselor about your difficulties adjusting to life here. The conversation turns out to be a good one. The counselor offers suggestions on how to relax and engage in social activities. She also recommends you take at least one fun class, like art, to ease your stress. Luckily, she doesn’t ask too much about your home life and you don’t reveal that you are living alone.

Unwilling to go against your mother’s wishes regarding the counselor, you turn to video games to decompress. Many of your buddies are playing a free online game that you find super fun and even a little addictive. It distracts you from your homesickness, but keeps you up late at night and does little to help your grades.

Although it would be better for your English development to venture away from this area, you’re too nervous to make a big trip alone to a part of the city where you might not be able to ask for help in Chinese. Besides, it helps ease the culture shock to be around what is familiar, even if assimilating to the larger U.S. culture is more difficult.

You decide to muster the courage to explore parts of the city that aren’t reminders of home. It will be a difficult experience, but you understand this adventure will be good for your language development, even if it worsens your homesickness.

You decide to take off for a few days to compile your thoughts. You head to a friend’s house in Torrance and ignore your parents’ calls. One night you listen to a message from your mother who says your father is sick with worry. Hearing her panicky voice, you realize you’ve behaved selfishly. You decide to head back to Arcadia.

You decide to call your mentor at the Education Center before making a rash decision. You talk for over an hour about the difficulties you're facing and how they are only temporary. Apparently, your mentor had a similar meltdown when he was a high school senior and regretted following through on the impulse to run away. After the conversation, you decide to return home.

You convince the counselor to change a few of your classes to AP. The move takes an incredible amount of work just to fulfill the requirements of the classes, leaving little room for a social life. Still, you enjoy the more challenging material and hope you can perform well enough on the AP tests to get some credit towards college classes when you graduate.

Concerned that you may not be able to handle the workload, the counselor doesn’t think AP-level classes would be a good fit. Although it hurts your self-esteem to be held back from taking more advanced classes, you know you’ll figure out other ways to get into college.

Concerned that you may not be able to handle the workload, you decide to stay in regular classes. Although you’d like to take more advanced classes, the regular classes do a good job of helping your language proficiency. The workload is also just right for you.
You decide that you’ll barely be able to focus even if you push yourself to study. Instead, you arm yourself with a queue full of Netflix and ride out the illness, which lasts only a few days.

Maybe you should have rested more. Maybe the illness wouldn’t have been so bad if you were able to see a doctor. But you decide to push on and continue working. Your hard work pays off, but you feel miserable for a week.

You decide to go out to the karaoke bar with your friends. After a long night of partying, your throat is sore from singing “I Want It That Way.” You haven't found time to relax, and this is the best you’ve felt for a while. The experience leaves you hooked. Unfortunately, your new nighttime hobby sends your grades plunging.
You pass on the karaoke mic and crack open your textbook. Your friends are disappointed you don’t join them, and a part of you is also disappointed. But you did really well on that science test.

You decide to join the track team, and it turns out to be a good call. The physical exercise helps you deal with your stress, and since most of the students on the team speak English, your English improves as well. However, spending several days a week after school training has reduced your studying time.

You tell your friend that you’re not joining the team. While this allows you to spend more time studying and improving your grades, a part of you is bummed you didn’t join the team. It’s hard to balance having what you consider a traditional American experience with the pressure to succeed academically in an unfamiliar place.
none
none
